Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Electrocorticographic Monitoring in Severe Traumatic Brain Injury

Participants.evidence: Patients undergoing surgery for severe TBI with subdural electrode placement were eligible. This randomised controlled trial was conducted in an intensive care setting.

Intervention.evidence: randomised 1:1 to standard care or a tiered intervention protocol targeting SD suppression

Objective.evidence: This trial evaluates the feasibility and efficacy of a treatment protocol guided by electrocorticographic monitoring of SDs.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the reduction in secondary injury, measured over 10 days.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the intervention and 100 to the control group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on 98 intervention and 97 control participants using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group showed a significant reduction in secondary injury (mean difference = 5.2, 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were reported in 3% of the intervention group and 1% of the control group.
